title: Enjoy Pep Guardiola while you can - this could be his last season at Man City
text:

Sergio Aguero was not telling us anything we did not strongly suspect but his words still gave a clear insight into the character of Pep Guardiola.

“When Pep arrived, I was a bit taken aback by his intensity,” says Aguero in a book about Guardiola’s time in ­Manchester so far.

“Pep is super intense. He won’t leave you alone for a second. There are no off days. He’s a real worrier, too.”

And you suspect there are no off days even when his players are away for the best part of a fortnight on ­international duty as Guardiola ­addresses a sticky start to the Premier League season.

(Image: REUTERS)

He took last Sunday’s home defeat to Wolves pretty calmly, just as he was phlegmatic about the reverse at ­Carrow Road.

But the odds against those two ­results were enormous. It was a 500-1 double.

Of course it is ludicrously early to start calling the title Liverpool’s to lose but if City do not defend their crown, they will reflect on those games as defining defeats.

And Guardiola will painstakingly analyse his own ‘performances’ in those fixtures.

(Image: PETER POWELL/EPA-EFE/REX)

Did he select the right team? Should Bernardo Silva have played from the start against Wolves?

More crucially, he might be ­wondering if, after more than three years of his demands, the players can maintain the sort of intensity Aguero refers to.

There are also long-term challenges ahead.

This will be 33-year-old David Silva’s final season at the Etihad, Fernandinho turns 35 next May, Aguero 32 in June.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Guardiola has a contract until the summer of 2021 and if he sees it out, that will have been five years at City – one more year than he spent as ­Barcelona manager before calling an emotional end to his tenure at the Nou Camp.

“I have given everything and I have nothing left and need to recharge my batteries,” Guardiola said when he left his beloved Barca. “The demands have been great and I have not been able to rest much.”

Now in his fourth year at City no one could deny Guardiola – whose wife Cristina will now be spending more time at home in Spain – has given and continues to give ­everything.

He had admitted to being ­‘exhausted’ after winning a ­treble last season and ­following up on seasons when his team accumulated 100 points and 98 points was always going to be a­ ­mountainous challenge.

(Image: Manchester City FC via Getty Ima)

While Jurgen Klopp appears to have the same intensity as Guardiola, the pressure has, arguably, been less for the German.

Guardiola, with his track record and with the lavish investment of his club’s owners, has been expected to deliver from day one.

He has even suggested he will be deemed some sort of failure if a Champions League is not delivered.

He will not, of course. But that sort of expectation has to weigh heavily on Guardiola’s shoulders.

(Image: PA)

While the prospect would be ­wonderful not just for City fans but for football fans in general, the idea that Guardiola would create a Sir Alex Ferguson-style dynasty at the Etihad was always fanciful in the extreme.

It is unlikely his two friends at the top of the power-chain, Ferran ­Soriano and Txiki Begiristain, believe their man will extend his stay beyond the end of his current deal.

Neither, though, would he walk out during a season.

(Image: PA)

But to win a third successive ­Premier League title from this ­position and go deep into the Champions League with a squad that, for all its brilliance, has glaring defensive deficiencies, will take a Herculean effort.

And that is why it would be no ­surprise at all if this season was ­Guardiola’s last. And that is why we should all enjoy him while we can.
description: Pep's contract runs out in 2021 but it could be his last season in Manchester
authors: Manchester City Fc Via Getty Ima
